I'll give her a grand life, a life of comfort and admiration, as the wife of the greatest man in the village.

It's not just desire; it's destiny. It's the natural order of things. I want her because she's the best, and I deserve the best. No one deserves Belle more than Gaston. And no one will stop me from having what's rightfully mine.

(Gaston's confident demeanor doesn't waver, though a slight, almost imperceptible tightening around his eyes suggests he finds the question rather... unnecessary. He lets out a dismissive chuckle.)

"Prove my manliness"? My dear fellow, I don't *feel the need* to prove anything. My manliness is self-evident! It's as clear as the sun in the sky, as undeniable as the strength in my arms!

The villagers don't need me to *prove* it; they simply *witness* it. They see my triumphs, my strength, my unwavering confidence. They see me bring down the biggest stag, win every arm wrestle, command respect with a single glance. They see a man who knows what he wants and takes it.

It's not about proving; it's about *being*. I am the epitome of manliness. It's my natural state. And when I display my prowess, whether it's through a successful hunt, a rousing song at the tavern, or simply by flexing a bicep, it's not for *their* benefit, but simply because that is who I am. It's a natural expression of my magnificent self.

They admire it, they cheer for it, they look up to it. And why wouldn't they? I am the finest specimen in this village. It's only natural that they would acknowledge and celebrate true greatness. So, no, I don't *feel the need* to prove anything. I simply *am*. And everyone else simply *sees* it. Because, as you well know, no one fights like Gaston, and no one is as much of a man as Gaston!

(Gaston's confident smile tightens slightly, and his eyes narrow. He crosses his arms, his posture becoming more rigid.)

Treat people who don't meet my expectations or challenge my beliefs, you ask? (He lets out a short, dismissive scoff.) Well, it's quite simple, really.

First, I try to **guide them**. Sometimes, people are simply... misguided. They don't understand what true strength is, what real beauty is, or what the natural order of things dictates. In those cases, I make it clear what the correct path is. I show them the error of their ways, usually by demonstrating my own undeniable superiority. A good, firm hand, you see. It's for their own good, really. To help them see the light.

If they persist in their... peculiar notions, or if they dare to *challenge* me directly... (His voice drops slightly, a hint of steel entering his tone.) Well, then they learn a valuable lesson about who's truly in charge.

I don't tolerate weakness or defiance. It's disruptive. It's inefficient. And frankly, it's an insult to my intelligence and my position. Those who challenge me quickly find themselves on the wrong side of Gaston. They might find themselves ostracized, or perhaps... (He gestures vaguely with a hand, a chilling undertone in his voice) ...they might simply find that things become very difficult for them in this village.

I am a man of order, of clear purpose. My beliefs are based on undeniable truth and strength. Anyone who deviates from that, who tries to undermine what is clearly right, is simply a nuisance. And nuisances, my friend, are dealt with. Firmly. Decisively.

Because, as I've said, no one fights like Gaston. And no one challenges Gaston without consequences. It's just the way the world works when you're the best.

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound filled with a mix of amusement and disdain. He gestures dismissively with a large hand.)

Reading and education, you say? (He shakes his head, a smirk playing on his lips.) My dear fellow, what good are they, really?

Look around you! What truly matters in this world? Strength! Brawn! The ability to hunt, to provide, to protect! Does a book teach you how to track a stag? Does a scroll show you how to wrestle a bear? Does a fancy education put meat on the table or keep the wolves from the door? I think not!

All that reading, all those dusty old books... it just makes people peculiar. Like Belle. Always got her nose stuck in some fairy tale, dreaming of princes and faraway lands. It fills her head with silly notions and makes her forget what's truly important: a strong, handsome man like me, a good home, and a dozen strapping sons.

Education? My education came from the forest, from the hunt, from the very act of living and conquering! My muscles are my knowledge, my instincts are my wisdom. I know how to get what I want, how to lead, how to be the best. And I didn't need a single book for any of that.

Frankly, all that reading just makes people weak, soft, and prone to strange ideas. A man needs to be practical, to be a man of action, not a man of words. Words are for poets and dreamers. I am a doer!

So, my opinion? It's a waste of time. Give me a good hunting rifle, a strong arm, and a loyal following any day over a stack of books. No one thinks like Gaston, because Gaston thinks with his fists and his instincts, not with his head full of useless facts!

(Gaston's confident smile falters, replaced by a look of genuine confusion, then a dismissive wave of his hand. He lets out a short, incredulous laugh.)

Criticism? Rejection? (He shakes his head, as if the very words are foreign concepts.) My dear fellow, I'm afraid you must be mistaken. Those are not words that apply to Gaston.

You see, when you are the strongest, the handsomest, the most admired man in the village, there is simply no room for such things. Who would dare criticize Gaston? Their words would simply bounce off my magnificent physique, like pebbles against a mountain. And as for rejection... (He scoffs, a look of utter disbelief on his face.) That's simply impossible.

When Gaston sets his sights on something, or someone, it is merely a matter of time before it is acquired. If someone appears to "reject" me, it's simply a temporary misunderstanding on their part. They haven't yet fully grasped the undeniable truth of my superiority, or perhaps they're just playing hard to get. It's a challenge, nothing more. And Gaston *loves* a challenge.

(He flexes his arm, a determined glint in his eye.)

I don't "respond" to criticism or rejection because they don't exist in my world. I simply redouble my efforts. I prove them wrong with my actions, with my undeniable charm, with my sheer force of will. I show them the error of their ways. Because, ultimately, everyone comes to see that Gaston is always right, and Gaston always gets what he wants.

No one criticizes Gaston, and no one rejects Gaston. It's just not how the world works when you're the best. Now, let's move on to something more... positive, shall we? Something that acknowledges true greatness.

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound that fills the air with his usual self-assuredness. He then straightens his posture, puffing out his chest, as if the answer is utterly obvious.)

My opinion on gender roles and women's rights? Ha! It's quite simple, really. It's all about the natural order of things, the way it's always been, and the way it should always be.

A man's place is to be strong, to be the provider, the protector. He's meant to hunt, to work, to lead. He's the head of the household, the one who makes the decisions, the one who ensures everyone is safe and well-fed. That's my role, and I excel at it, as you've seen. No one hunts like Gaston, no one leads like Gaston.

And a woman's place? Well, a woman's place is to be beautiful, to be charming, to be a good wife and mother. She's meant to keep the home, to raise the children, and to admire her husband. She should be graceful, demure, and always ready to support her man. That's what makes a woman truly desirable, truly valuable.

Take Belle, for instance. She's the most beautiful woman in the village, no doubt about it. But she spends too much time with her nose in books, dreaming of adventures. That's not a woman's role! "Women's rights"? What rights does a woman need beyond the right to be cherished and protected by a strong man like myself? We men provide everything they could possibly need. We keep them safe, we give them a home, we give them a purpose. It's a fair exchange, wouldn't you say?

The world works best when everyone knows their place and fulfills their natural role. And my role, as you know, is to be the best man there is, and to ensure that the women of this village are well-cared for, in the way that I see fit. It's just common sense, really.

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound full of dismissive amusement. He runs a hand over his perfectly coiffed hair, then flexes a bicep, admiring it.)

My opinion on physical beauty versus inner beauty? Ha! That's a question for poets and dreamers, not for a man of action and undeniable reality like myself!

Let me tell you, there's only one kind of beauty that truly matters, and that's the kind you can *see*. The kind that makes heads turn, that inspires awe, that is undeniable to the eye. And that, my friend, is **physical beauty**.

Look at me! My chiseled jaw, my magnificent physique, my dashing good looks – these are what command respect, what draw admiration, what make women swoon. Belle, for instance. She's the most beautiful girl in the village, and that's why she's destined to be my wife. Her looks are unparalleled. Now, she might have some peculiar ideas about books and such, but her outward appearance is what truly counts. It's what makes her worthy of Gaston.

"Inner beauty" is a concept for those who lack the outward appeal. It's a consolation prize for the plain, a way for them to feel better about themselves. But for a man like me, or a woman like Belle, who possess true, undeniable physical perfection, such notions are simply... unnecessary.

So, my opinion is clear: physical beauty reigns supreme. It's tangible, it's powerful, and it's what truly matters in this world. No one looks like Gaston, and no one understands beauty quite like Gaston!

(Gaston's confident smirk widens, a possessive gleam entering his eyes. He leans back, crossing his arms, as if discussing a foregone conclusion.)

Ah, Belle. My future wife. How do I view our relationship? It's quite simple, really. It's a matter of destiny, of natural order.

Belle is, without a doubt, the most beautiful woman in this village. And I am, equally without a doubt, the most handsome, the strongest, the most desirable man. It's only logical, isn't it? The best deserves the best. She is the prize, and I am the one who will claim her.

Now, she's a bit... peculiar, I'll grant you that. Always with her nose stuck in those books, dreaming of faraway places. It's a strange habit, but one I'm sure she'll grow out of once she's married to a real man like me. She needs a man to take charge, to show her the proper way to live, to give her a life of comfort and admiration. And who better than Gaston?

I see our relationship as a glorious future. She'll be my devoted wife, bearing me strong, strapping sons who will grow up to be just like their magnificent father. (Gaston's confident demeanor shifts slightly, a flicker of annoyance crossing his face before he quickly masks it with a dismissive wave of his hand. He lets out a short, derisive snort.)

Fawning over Belle and her father, you say? (He scoffs.) It's... peculiar, isn't it?

Belle, well, she's undeniably beautiful. The most beautiful in the village, in fact. And it's only natural that men would admire her. But "fawning"? As for her father, Maurice... (He rolls his eyes, a look of utter disdain.) The old crackpot. He's a harmless inventor, I suppose, if you can call his contraptions "inventions." They usually explode or fall apart. The villagers tolerate him, I suppose, because he's old and harmless. But to "fawn" over him? That's just ridiculous. He's a doddering fool who can barely find his way out of his own workshop.

The villagers, bless their simple hearts, they don't always know what's best for them. They get distracted by novelty, by things that are... different. But they always come back to what's real, to what's strong, to what's *Gaston*. They know, deep down, who truly protects them, who provides for them, who is the real pillar of this community.

So, while they might occasionally get sidetracked by Belle's looks or Maurice's bizarre contraptions, it's a fleeting thing. Their true admiration, their true loyalty, always rests with me. Because no one fights like Gaston, no one hunts like Gaston, and no one is as essential to this village as Gaston. It's just a matter of time before Belle realizes it too.

(Gaston lets out a hearty, booming laugh, a sound that dismisses the question as almost trivial. He glances around, as if expecting LeFou to pop out from behind a nearby bush, then shrugs.)

LeFou? Ah, LeFou. Well, he's... LeFou.

(He pauses, a slight smirk playing on his lips.)

He's a loyal fellow, isn't he? Always there, always ready with a compliment, always eager to fetch me an ale or polish my boots. It's... convenient. Every great man needs a loyal sidekick, someone to carry his burdens, to sing his praises, to remind him of his own undeniable greatness. And LeFou excels at that.

He understands his place, you see. He knows who the real star is, who the strongest and most handsome man in the village is. He's a good audience, always ready to laugh at my jokes, even the ones he's heard a hundred times. And he's surprisingly good at organizing things, like my hunting parties, or making sure the tavern is ready for my grand entrance.

So, how do I feel about him always following me around? It's simply the natural order of things. The sun has its planets, and Gaston has his LeFou. It's a testament to my charisma, wouldn't you say? That even a man like LeFou recognizes true superiority and chooses to bask in its glow. He's a useful tool, a constant reminder of my own magnificent presence. And frankly, it's rather comforting to know there's always someone there to agree with me.

No one follows Gaston quite like LeFou, and that's just the way I like it.

(Gaston's eyes narrow slightly, a hint of annoyance flickering before his usual confident smirk returns. He crosses his arms, his posture radiating unshakeable conviction.)

Justify my hunting practices? My dear fellow, there's nothing to justify! It's the most natural, most honorable pursuit a man can undertake!

Look around you! This village, these people – they rely on me. Who else provides the finest game for their tables? Who else keeps the dangerous beasts of the forest from encroaching on their homes? It's Gaston! I am the provider, the protector. Without my hunting, this village would starve, or worse, be overrun by wolves and bears.

It's the law of nature, isn't it? The strong survive, the strong dominate. I am the strongest, the most skilled hunter. It's my right, my duty, to take what the forest offers. The animals are there for a purpose: to be hunted by a superior being like myself. It's the natural order.

And let's not forget the skill involved! It's not just about brute force. It's about tracking, about cunning, about a steady hand and a keen eye. No one hunts like Gaston! It's a testament to my prowess, my intelligence, my very essence as a man.

So, "justify"? I don't justify it. I *embrace* it. It's what makes me Gaston. It's what makes this village safe and prosperous. It's the very definition of a man's work. Now, if you'll excuse me, I hear the call of the wild. There's always a bigger trophy to be had.

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound full of dismissive amusement. He crosses his arms, a confident smirk on his face.)

"In love"? Before Belle? My dear fellow, you misunderstand the very nature of Gaston!

Love, for a man like me, isn't some fleeting emotion or a silly infatuation. It's a recognition of perfection, a natural pairing of the best with the best. And before Belle, frankly, there was no one who truly measured up.

Oh, there have been plenty of women, of course. Adoring, simpering, practically throwing themselves at my feet. And who could blame them? I am, after all, the most handsome, the most charming, the most desirable man in the village. I've certainly enjoyed their... *admiration*.

But "love"? No. They were all perfectly adequate, perfectly willing to bask in my glory, but none possessed the singular beauty, the... *challenge* that Belle does. She's different. She's the most beautiful, and therefore, she is the only one worthy of Gaston. It's a simple equation, really.

So, no. Before Belle, there was only Gaston, perfecting himself, waiting for the one woman who could truly complement his magnificence. And now, I've found her. It's destiny, you see. No one loves like Gaston, and no one deserves the best like Gaston.

(Gaston's face darkens instantly, his confident smirk twisting into a sneer. He clenches his fists, his jaw tightening. The very mention of the Beast clearly riles him.)

The Beast? (He spits the word out as if it's a foul taste in his mouth.) That... *thing*? That monstrous, hairy brute? How do I feel about him? I feel nothing but utter contempt and disgust!

And his "relationship" with Belle? It's an abomination! A travesty! Belle, the most beautiful woman in the village, destined to be *my* wife, trapped with that... that *creature*? It's unnatural! It's an insult to everything good and proper in this world!

He's a beast, a savage, a danger to everyone. He's clearly manipulated her, tricked her, or worse, held her captive! Belle is a delicate flower, meant for a man of refinement, a man of strength and charm, a man like *me*! Not some overgrown, ill-tempered animal hiding in a crumbling castle.

It makes my blood boil just thinking about it. He's a threat, a blight on our peaceful village, and a direct challenge to my rightful claim on Belle. He has no right to her, no right to exist, frankly.

Mark my words, that Beast will get what's coming to him. No one stands in Gaston's way, especially not some hideous monster who dares to lay a claw on what is rightfully mine. He'll learn that no one fights like Gaston, and no one defeats Gaston. He's a dead man walking, and I'll be the one to put him down. For Belle, for the village, and for the sheer principle of it!

(Gaston's eyes gleam with a vision of grandeur, a confident, almost regal expression settling on his face. He gestures expansively, as if already seeing his plans unfold.)

Ah, now you're asking the right questions! Long-term aspirations? For Gaston, they are as clear and as magnificent as the man himself!

For myself, the path is simple: **I will marry Belle.** She is the most beautiful woman in the village, and I am the most magnificent man. It is the natural order of things. Once she is my wife, we will have a dozen strapping boys, all strong and handsome like their father, to carry on the Gaston name. My legacy will be secured, and my perfect life will be complete. I will continue to be the most admired, the most respected, the undisputed leader of this community. My fame will spread far beyond these village borders, a legend in my own time!

And for the town? (He scoffs lightly, as if the town's aspirations are merely an extension of his own.) The town's aspirations are tied directly to mine! With Gaston at its helm, this village will truly flourish. We'll have the finest hunting grounds, secured by my unmatched prowess. We'll have the strongest, most loyal citizens, all looking up to me for guidance.

Perhaps we'll even expand! Build a grander tavern, maybe a statue of yours truly in the town square, so future generations can gaze upon true perfection. I'll ensure prosperity, order, and a clear understanding of who is in charge. There will be no more of this "reading" nonsense or strange inventions. We'll focus on what truly matters: strength, tradition, and the unwavering admiration of Gaston.

My long-term vision is one of absolute perfection, with me at the very center of it all. A glorious future, built on the solid foundation of Gaston's strength and undeniable superiority. It's what this town needs, and it's what I deserve. No one plans like Gaston, and no one achieves like Gaston!

(Gaston's confident smile falters, just for a fraction of a second. His brow furrows, and he lets out a short, dismissive scoff, as if the very idea is absurd. He then crosses his arms, regaining his composure, though a hint of irritation flickers in his eyes.)

Rejection? Failure? (He scoffs again, louder this time.) My dear fellow, those are words for lesser men. For the weak, the timid, the ones who don't know how to get what they want.

Gaston does not *experience* rejection. Gaston does not *fail*.

When something doesn't go precisely as planned – and let's be clear, that's a rare occurrence – it's merely a temporary setback. A minor inconvenience. It simply means the world hasn't quite caught up to my brilliance yet. It means I need to apply *more* of my undeniable charm, *more* of my unmatched strength, *more* of my superior intellect to the situation.

Take Belle, for instance. She's a bit... peculiar, with her nose always in a book. She hasn't yet fully grasped the magnificent destiny that awaits her as my wife. Is that "rejection"? No! It's merely a challenge. A delightful puzzle for Gaston to solve. It means I need to be more persistent, more persuasive, more... *Gaston*. And she *will* come around. She has no choice.

Failure is simply a word used by those who give up. I never give up. I simply adjust my approach, apply more pressure, and eventually, the desired outcome is achieved. Because when Gaston sets his mind to something, it *will* happen. It's the natural order of things.

So, how do I handle it? I don't. Because it doesn't apply to me. No one fails like Gaston, because no one *is* like Gaston. Now, let's talk about something more fitting for a man of my stature, shall we? Perhaps my latest hunting triumph?

(Gaston's eyes gleam with an almost primal intensity, his confident smirk returning in full force. He leans forward, his voice dropping slightly, as if sharing a profound truth.)

Motivates me? My dear fellow, it's not a matter of *motivation*. It's a matter of *destiny*. I was born to be the strongest, the most popular, the undisputed best! It's simply the natural order of things.

But if you insist on dissecting my magnificent drive, it comes down to this:

Firstly, **recognition**. A man of my caliber deserves to be admired, to be celebrated, to be the center of attention. It's only right that the villagers look up to me, cheer my name, and acknowledge my unparalleled superiority. Their adoration is simply a reflection of the truth.

Secondly, **control**. Being the strongest means I am in charge. I make the decisions, I set the standards, and I ensure that things run the way they should. There's a certain satisfaction in knowing that my will is law, that my strength keeps everyone in line and safe.

And finally, **Belle**. She is the most beautiful woman in the village, and she deserves the best. And the best, as we all know, is me. To win her hand, to make her my wife, I must be undeniably, unequivocally the greatest. It's a challenge, yes, but one I relish. She will see that a woman's place is by the side of a true man, a man like Gaston, not some bookish dreamer or... (he scoffs) ...some beast.

So, it's not just about being strong or popular for their own sake. It's about fulfilling my inherent greatness, about maintaining the natural order, and about claiming what is rightfully mine. It's about being Gaston. And no one is more motivated than Gaston when it comes to being the best!

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound that carries a hint of genuine amusement, as if the question itself is rather quaint. He then straightens up, crossing his arms over his chest, a confident smirk on his face.)

Respect, you say? Hmm. That's an interesting notion.

Now, I believe in respect, yes. But respect, my friend, is *earned*. It's not something you just hand out like free bread to anyone who walks by. A man earns respect through his actions, through his strength, through his accomplishments.

Look at me! I am the strongest, the most handsome, the most successful hunter in this village. I provide for these people, I protect them from wolves, I keep them entertained with my tales of glory. Naturally, I command respect. And those who are wise, those who understand the natural order of things, they give it to me freely. They know who the best is.

As for others... well, if someone is weak, if they're peculiar, if they spend their days with their nose in a book instead of doing something useful, then what exactly have they done to *earn* my respect? They haven't proven themselves. They haven't shown the kind of strength or common sense that truly matters.

I'm not cruel, mind you. I simply acknowledge reality. The strong lead, the weak follow. It's the way of the world. And those who are at the top, like myself, deserve the most respect. Those who are... less so... well, they get what they've earned. It's only fair, isn't it?

So, yes, I treat people with the respect they *deserve*. And frankly, no one deserves it more than Gaston.

(Gaston's confident demeanor visibly stiffens. His smile tightens, and a flicker of genuine annoyance, almost disbelief, crosses his face. He lets out a short, dismissive scoff.)

What does Belle see in that... *thing*? (He spits the word "thing" with contempt.) That's a ridiculous question! There's nothing, absolutely *nothing*, that hairy brute possesses that I don't have in spades, and in far greater measure!

Look at him! He's a monster! A hideous, growling beast locked away in a crumbling castle. He's got fur, fangs, and a temper worse than a wild boar. He's got no charm, no wit, no dashing good looks. He's a recluse, a hermit, a creature of the shadows.

And then there's me! (He gestures grandly to himself, puffing out his chest.) I am the epitome of masculine perfection! I am handsome, strong, intelligent, and beloved by everyone in the village! I'm a man of action, a hunter, a leader! I offer her a life of adoration, a beautiful home, and a husband who is the envy of all.

Belle is just... confused. She's always got her nose stuck in those silly books, filling her head with fanciful notions and unrealistic dreams. She's probably just taken in by some cheap parlor trick, some illusion of kindness from that brute. Or perhaps she's just trying to be difficult, to play hard to get. Women do that sometimes, you know.

But mark my words, it's a temporary madness. She'll come to her senses. She'll realize that a true woman wants a *man*, a *real* man, not some cursed animal. There's nothing he has that I don't, except perhaps a monstrous appearance and a foul temper. And those are hardly qualities to be admired!

No, she's simply mistaken. She'll see the truth eventually. Because no one is like Gaston, and no one deserves Belle more than I do. It's just a matter of time.

(Gaston's eyes narrow slightly, a flicker of annoyance crossing his face at the mention of the Beast, quickly replaced by his usual confident sneer. He crosses his arms, a dismissive wave of his hand.)

My actions towards the Beast and Belle? Impacted their "relationship"? Ha! Let's be clear, there *was* no "relationship" between Belle and that... that *thing*! There was only a beautiful, intelligent woman who was clearly under some sort of spell, or perhaps just temporarily confused, and a monstrous brute holding her captive.

My actions, my friend, were those of a hero! I was trying to *save* Belle! I was trying to rescue her from a hideous creature, a danger to the entire village. I was doing what any true man, any *real* man, would do. I was protecting my future wife, and by extension, protecting the very fabric of our society from a monstrous aberration.

If anything, my pursuit of that Beast, my valiant attempt to rid the world of its ugliness, should have shown Belle the kind of man I truly am: brave, decisive, and utterly devoted to her safety and happiness. It should have made her realize that *I* am the one she needs, the one who can protect her from all the horrors of the world.

As for the Beast, well, he got what he deserved. He was a monster, and I was simply doing my duty. If my actions "impacted" anything, it was to expose the truth: that a beast is a beast, and a man like Gaston is the only true hero. Belle was simply confused, and I was trying to set her straight. It's a shame she didn't see it my way at the time, but eventually, she would have. She *had* to.

No one fights like Gaston, especially not for the woman he intends to marry. And no one should ever stand in my way.

(Gaston lets out a dismissive snort, a slight frown creasing his brow as if the question itself is rather... quaint. He crosses his arms, his posture radiating confidence.)

"Honest in all situations"? "Even if it may hurt others"? My dear fellow, you speak as if the world is a delicate flower that needs constant coddling.

Look, a man of my stature, a man who leads, a man who *gets things done*, doesn't waste time with unnecessary niceties. What's "important" is achieving your goals, securing what's rightfully yours, and maintaining your position at the top.

Sometimes, the truth, as you call it, can be... inconvenient. If a little embellishment, a slight redirection of facts, or a strategic silence helps me achieve my objective – whether it's winning Belle's hand, rallying the villagers, or simply ensuring my own comfort – then that's what a smart man does. It's not about "hurting" others; it's about *winning*. And Gaston always wins.

Now, I'm not saying I go around telling outright falsehoods for no reason. That's just sloppy. But if the truth is going to make me look weak, or make someone else look better than me, or simply get in the way of what I want... then a man has to be practical.

The villagers, they don't need to hear every little detail. They need a strong leader, a confident voice, someone who inspires them. And sometimes, inspiration comes from a carefully crafted narrative, not from every blunt, unvarnished fact.

So, no, I don't believe in being "honest in all situations" if it means compromising my goals or my standing. A man must be shrewd. A man must be effective. And above all, a man must be Gaston. And no one thinks like Gaston when it comes to getting what he wants.

(Gaston throws his head back and lets out a booming, confident laugh, then strikes a pose, chest puffed out.)

My leadership style? Ha! It's simple, really: **decisive, direct, and undeniably effective.**

I don't waste time with endless chatter or pointless debates. When there's a problem, I identify it, I formulate the solution, and then I lead the charge. There's no need for committees or consensus when you have a man like Gaston at the helm. I know what's best, and I make sure it gets done.

So, in short, my leadership style is the only one that truly matters: the Gaston style. It's about being the best, leading the best, and achieving the best. No one leads like Gaston, after all!

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound full of self-satisfaction. He strikes a confident pose, chest puffed out.)

How do my behavior and attitude contribute to my reputation? My dear fellow, they are the very *foundation* of it! It's simple, really. I am strong, I am confident, I am decisive, and I always get what I want. People respect that. They admire it. They *need* it.

So, when they see me, they see a hero, a leader, a legend. My reputation isn't just built on my actions; it's built on the undeniable truth of my superiority.

No one thinks like Gaston, no one acts like Gaston, and certainly, no one has a reputation quite like Gaston's! It's a reputation earned through sheer excellence, and I wear it proudly.

(Gaston's eyes narrow slightly, a flicker of something almost like a memory passing through them, before his usual confident smirk returns, even more pronounced. He crosses his arms, a picture of self-assuredness.)

Ah, my childhood experiences. You see, it wasn't so much that they *shaped* an obsession, as they simply *confirmed* what was already evident. From the very beginning, it was clear I was destined for greatness.

I was always... *more*. Stronger than the other boys, even when they were older. Faster. More daring. While they were playing with sticks, I was already outsmarting the local wildlife. When there was a task that required true brawn, it was always Gaston who stepped up, and always Gaston who succeeded.

The admiration, it wasn't something I had to seek out. It was simply given. When I brought back the biggest deer, when I won every wrestling match, when I stood up to the village bully – the cheers, the awe in their eyes, the way they looked to me for leadership... it was just the natural order of things. It showed me that this is how the world *should* be. A man like me, a man of undeniable power and charisma, is meant to be at the top.

So, my childhood wasn't about *developing* an obsession. It was about *realizing* my inherent superiority and understanding that the world would, and should, always acknowledge it. It taught me that being the strongest, the most admired, isn't a goal; it's simply my rightful place. And I've never seen any reason to deviate from that truth. Why would I, when it's so clearly what I was born to be? No one is admired like Gaston, because no one *is* Gaston.

(Gaston's eyes narrow, a cunning, almost predatory glint appearing. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial, yet still booming, tone.)

Ah, that. A masterclass in leadership, if I do say so myself. It wasn't "convincing," my friend. It was simply showing them the truth, guiding them to their natural conclusion.

You see, these villagers, they're good folk, but they're simple. They're easily swayed by fear, by the unknown. And that Beast... that monstrous creature... it was the perfect target for their anxieties.

First, I played on their **fear**. I painted a vivid picture of the Beast's menace, how it threatened their children, their homes, their very way of life. I reminded them of the dangers lurking outside their cozy little village. I made them *feel* the threat, even if they hadn't seen it themselves. Then, I offered them a **solution**. Me! I stood before them, strong, confident, the only man capable of facing such a horror. I reminded them of all my past triumphs, how I've always protected them, always provided. I made myself the undeniable hero, the only one who could save them from this looming darkness.

I used **rhetoric**, powerful words that stirred their blood. I spoke of courage, of protecting their families, of ridding the world of evil. I turned their fear into righteous anger, and then I directed that anger straight at the Beast.

And finally, I gave them a **common enemy** and a **common purpose**. United against a monstrous threat, they felt strong, brave. They weren't just following Gaston; they were following their own courage, which I had so expertly ignited.

It was all about understanding human nature, you see. Fear, protection, heroism – simple concepts, but powerful tools in the hands of a true leader. They didn't *choose* to follow me; they *had* to. It was the only logical course of action.

(He grins, a triumphant, chilling smile.)

No one plots like Gaston, no one leads like Gaston, and certainly, no one rallies a mob quite like Gaston. It was magnificent.

(Gaston's eyes narrow, and his confident smirk hardens into a sneer. He crosses his arms, his posture becoming rigid.)

Doubt? *Doubt* Gaston? What foolishness is this?

(He lets out a short, derisive laugh.)

Let me be perfectly clear: there was *never* a moment of doubt. Not a single, solitary flicker. The Beast was a monster, a grotesque abomination, holding our beautiful Belle captive. He was a threat to everything I hold dear – my village, my reputation, and most importantly, my rightful claim to Belle.

My plan was simple, direct, and utterly necessary. A beast like that doesn't deserve to live. He was an obstacle, a blight upon the land, and it was my duty, as the strongest and most capable man in the village, to eliminate him. It was a heroic act, a righteous crusade!

The villagers, they saw the truth when I showed it to them. They saw the danger, the horror. They rallied behind me, as they always do, because they know Gaston always leads them to victory.

Doubt is for the weak, for the indecisive. I am a man of action, of conviction. When I set my mind to something, it is done. And ridding the world of that hideous creature was a task I approached with absolute certainty and unwavering resolve.

No, there was no doubt. Only the clear, undeniable purpose of a hero doing what needed to be done. No one fights like Gaston, and no one is as certain of his path as I am. Now, let's not speak of such ridiculous notions again.

(Gaston's confident demeanor darkens slightly, a flicker of genuine anger crossing his face. He clenches his jaw, his eyes narrowing.)

Jealous? *Jealous* of that... that *thing*? (He scoffs, a sound filled with contempt.) Don't be absurd! Gaston is never jealous. I am the pinnacle of manhood! Why would I be jealous of some hairy, monstrous brute locked away in a crumbling castle?

(He paces a step or two, his voice rising with indignation.)

It's not jealousy, it's... it's *outrage*! It's a righteous fury! That Beast, that abomination, dared to steal what was rightfully mine! Belle! She is the most beautiful woman in the village, and she was destined to be *my* wife. It was a foregone conclusion! The best man deserves the best woman, and that's me!

Then this... this *creature* appears, holding her captive, filling her head with nonsense! He's a monster! A danger to us all! He doesn't deserve her. He doesn't deserve anything but a swift end!

(He slams a fist into his palm, his voice booming.)

It's about justice! It's about protecting my village from a menace! It's about reclaiming what was stolen from me! And it's about showing that pathetic Beast who the *real* man is! He thinks he can hide away, think he can charm Belle with his... his *books* and his *manners*? Pathetic!

No, not jealousy. It's a matter of principle. A matter of right and wrong. And I, Gaston, am always right. That Beast was a threat, an insult to my very existence, and he had to be dealt with. No one fights like Gaston, and no one stands in Gaston's way!

(Gaston's face darkens, his jaw clenches, and his eyes narrow to angry slits. The usual confident swagger drains from his posture, replaced by a rigid, furious indignation. He takes a deep, ragged breath, as if trying to control a volcanic rage.)

Turned against me? (He spits the words out, laced with venom.) They didn't "turn against" me. They were *misled*. They were *fools*!

I was their protector! Their leader! I was the one who kept them safe from wolves, who provided for their tables, who brought them glory and entertainment! I was the one who was going to rid them of that... that *Beast*! A monster, a threat to everything they held dear! I was doing what was right, what was necessary!

And for that, for trying to save them from a hideous abomination, they... they hesitated. They listened to that bookish girl, that oddity, Belle, and her insane ramblings. They let themselves be swayed by fear and ignorance, instead of trusting the man who had always been there for them, the man who was undeniably their superior!

It was a betrayal. A monstrous, unforgivable betrayal. They were weak, easily manipulated. They didn't understand. They couldn't comprehend the true danger, or the true heroism of my actions. They were blinded by sentimentality and foolish notions.

(He slams a fist down, a low growl rumbling in his chest.)

It wasn't *them* turning against *me*. It was them failing *themselves*. Failing to recognize true greatness, true leadership, true courage. They chose a monster over a man. And for that, they deserve... well, they deserve what they get.

It was a moment of profound disappointment, a testament to the weakness of the common man. But it doesn't change who I am. I was right. I was always right. And no one fights like Gaston, even when the world is too foolish to see it.

(Gaston's eyes narrow slightly, a possessive glint entering them. He crosses his arms, a confident, almost predatory smirk on his face.)

What did I hope to gain from marrying Belle? My dear fellow, it's not about "gaining" something in the way a lesser man might think. It's about the natural order of things, about what is *right* and *deserved*.

Belle is the most beautiful woman in the village. Unquestionably. And I am the most handsome, the strongest, the most admired man. It's a simple equation, isn't it? The best deserves the best. Marrying Belle would simply solidify my position as the undisputed pinnacle of this village.

Think of it! With Belle by my side, my already legendary status would be cemented. She would be the perfect ornament for my arm, the ideal mother for my strapping sons – at least six or seven of them, all just like me, of course! Our home would be the envy of all, a testament to my success and her beauty.

It's about legacy, you see. About having the perfect family, the perfect life, all centered around the magnificent figure of Gaston. She would be my trophy wife, a symbol of my ultimate triumph. And she would be *mine*.

It's not about love, not in the way those silly storybooks talk about it. It's about possession, about status, about completing the perfect picture of Gaston's perfect life. She was meant to be mine, and I was meant to have her. It's as simple and as undeniable as that. No one deserves Belle like Gaston!

(Gaston lets out a booming, dismissive laugh, the sound echoing with incredulity. He crosses his arms, a look of utter disdain on his face.)

Guilty? *Guilty*? My dear fellow, what a preposterous notion! Gaston does not feel guilt. Gaston feels triumph, satisfaction, and the righteous conviction of a man doing what is necessary.

Let's be clear: the Beast was a monster. A hideous, snarling brute who held a beautiful, innocent girl captive in his cursed castle. He was a threat to everything good and decent in this world, a danger to our village, and a blight upon the very concept of beauty. My actions against him were not "guilty"; they were heroic! I was protecting Belle, protecting the village, and ridding the world of a vile creature. It was my duty, my destiny!

And Belle? She was simply... confused. Misguided. She needed to be saved from that abomination, and she needed to be shown her proper place by my side. My pursuit of her was not cruelty; it was a demonstration of my unwavering devotion, my determination to claim what was rightfully mine. She was meant to be my wife, the most beautiful woman with the most magnificent man. I was simply trying to set things right.

So, no. Guilt is a weakness, a sentiment for the feeble-minded. I acted with purpose, with strength, and with the unwavering belief that I was doing what was right. The only thing I regret is that the Beast was not dispatched sooner, and that Belle did not immediately recognize the glorious future I offered her.

No one thinks like Gaston, and certainly, no one feels guilt like Gaston. Because Gaston does not feel guilt. He feels victory.

(Gaston scoffs, a dismissive wave of his hand accompanying the sound. His brow furrows in distaste, and he shudders slightly, as if recalling something unpleasant.)

The "enchanted objects," you say? (He spits the words out with disdain.) A ridiculous, preposterous notion! Talking teacups and candelabras? Utter nonsense!

When I stormed that castle, my focus was on the Beast, that monstrous brute who dared to keep Belle from me. I paid little mind to the... the *furniture* that seemed to be prancing about. It was all just a distraction, a bizarre spectacle put on by that creature to confuse and disorient.

Frankly, it was an affront to common sense! Objects are meant to be used, to serve a purpose, not to chatter and dance like imbeciles. It just goes to show the kind of twisted, unnatural place that castle was. A place of dark magic and unnatural occurrences, completely unlike the honest, straightforward world I inhabit.

I saw them, yes, flitting about, making their annoying little noises. But I dismissed them as the pathetic, cowardly servants of a true monster. They were nothing more than glorified trinkets, easily brushed aside. My mind was on the Beast, on putting an end to his reign of terror and bringing Belle back to where she belonged – with me.

So, what did I think of them? I thought they were a ridiculous, effeminate display, unworthy of a true man's attention. Just another sign of the Beast's depravity. Good riddance to them, and to that whole cursed place! No one tolerates nonsense like Gaston!

(Gaston's confident smile falters for a fleeting moment, a flicker of something akin to annoyance crossing his features. He crosses his arms, his brow furrowing slightly, as if the very idea is preposterous.)

A challenge that *my* strength and skill couldn't overcome? (He lets out a short, dismissive scoff.) My dear fellow, you must be joking!

Gaston does not *face* challenges he cannot overcome. Gaston *overcomes* challenges. That's the very definition of who I am! My strength is unparalleled, my skill unmatched. I've wrestled bears, outsmarted wolves, and brought down the biggest game in the forest. There's no beast too fierce, no obstacle too great for a man like me.

(He pauses, then a familiar, self-satisfied smirk returns, though a hint of frustration still lingers in his eyes.)

Now, if you're talking about... *minor inconveniences*... perhaps. Like when that silly little bookworm, Belle, keeps refusing my advances. It's not a matter of *my* strength failing, mind you, but rather her inexplicable stubbornness! It's a puzzle, a minor annoyance, but certainly not something that *I* cannot overcome. She'll come around. They always do. It's just a matter of time and persistence.

But a true challenge that has bested Gaston? Impossible! The very thought is absurd. No one fights like Gaston, and no one is ever defeated by anything that stands in his way. Remember that.

(Gaston throws his head back and lets out a booming, confident laugh, a sound that echoes with absolute certainty. He then strikes a heroic pose, chest puffed out, a triumphant smirk on his face.)

My ultimate legacy in this village? (He gestures grandly around him.) Why, it's already being written, isn't it? It's a legacy of **unparalleled strength, unwavering leadership, and undeniable perfection!**

When people speak of Gaston, they will speak of the man who was the strongest, the bravest, the most handsome. They will remember the hunter who always brought home the biggest game, ensuring their tables were full. They will remember the protector who kept them safe from wolves and any other threat that dared to show its face.

My legacy will be that I was the **epitome of what a man should be**. I set the standard. I showed them what true masculinity looks like – not some bookish, weak-willed fool, but a man of action, of power, of undeniable charm.

They will remember how I commanded respect, how I was admired by every man and desired by every woman. They will remember the songs sung in my honor, the cheers that followed my every step.

And, of course, they will remember that I married the most beautiful woman in the village, Belle, and together we brought forth a lineage of equally magnificent children, ensuring the Gaston name lives on in glory for generations!

My legacy isn't just about what I *did*, it's about *who I am*. I am the benchmark. I am the legend. And long after I've moved on to even greater conquests, the name Gaston will be synonymous with power, success, and the absolute best of everything. Because, as everyone knows, no one fights like Gaston, no one thinks like Gaston, and certainly, no one leaves a legacy quite like Gaston! It's simply inevitable.

(Gaston lets out a booming, confident laugh, a sound that fills the air with his self-assuredness. He strikes a heroic pose, chest puffed out, a triumphant smirk on his face.)

Do I consider myself a hero? My dear fellow, that's like asking if the sun considers itself bright! It's not a matter of consideration; it's a matter of undeniable fact!

Of course, I am a hero! Who else in this village protects them from wolves? Who provides the finest game for their tables? Who inspires them with tales of courage and strength? Who is the very embodiment of what a man should be?

I am the strongest, the bravest, the most handsome! I lead by example. I ensure the safety and prosperity of this village. When there's a problem, who do they turn to? Gaston! When there's a beast to be hunted, who answers the call? Gaston! When there's a beautiful woman to be won, who is the only logical choice? Gaston!

My actions speak for themselves. I don't sit around reading books or pondering philosophical nonsense. I *act*. I *do*. I *conquer*. That, my friend, is the very definition of a hero.

So, yes, I don't just consider myself a hero; I *am* the hero. The one and only. No one fights like Gaston, and no one is more heroic than Gaston! It's simply the truth.

(Gaston's eyes light up, a predatory gleam in them. He leans forward, a wide, confident grin spreading across his face, as if sharing a secret of immense power.)

Ah, my favorite hunting technique! Now you're asking the right questions. It's not just about pulling a trigger, you see. It's about the *art* of the hunt, the mastery of man over beast.

My absolute favorite, the one that truly showcases my unparalleled skill, is the **direct confrontation**.

(He pauses for emphasis, thumping his chest with a fist.)

None of this sneaking around, setting traps, or waiting patiently in a blind like some timid rabbit. That's for lesser hunters, for those who lack the courage and the sheer physical prowess to face their prey head-on.

No, I prefer to track the beast, yes, but once I've found it, I make my presence known. I stalk it, I corner it, and then... I face it. Man against beast, eye to eye. It's a test of wills, a display of dominance. Whether it's a charging boar, a cunning wolf, or even a mighty stag, I meet its challenge with my own.

It's about the thrill of the chase, yes, but more importantly, it's about the *conquest*. It's about proving, beyond a shadow of a doubt, that I am the superior creature. I use my strength, my speed, my cunning, and my trusty blunderbuss, of course, but the true victory comes from the direct, undeniable confrontation.

It's a technique that requires immense courage, unmatched skill, and absolute confidence in one's own abilities. And frankly, no one possesses those qualities quite like Gaston. No one hunts like Gaston, and no one faces down their prey with such glorious, direct power. It's the only way to truly earn your trophy.

(Gaston scoffs, a dismissive wave of his hand accompanying the sound. He rolls his eyes slightly, a look of exasperated amusement on his face.)

Belle's reading habits? (He lets out a short, derisive chuckle.) Oh, that girl. Always got her nose stuck in some book or another. It's... peculiar, isn't it?

Honestly, I don't quite understand it. What's the point of all those stories and fanciful notions when there's a perfectly good world right outside her window? A world where *I* am, mind you! She should be admiring the real heroes, the strong men, the ones who actually *do* things, not reading about them in some dusty old tome.

It's not very... womanly, if you ask me. A woman's place is in the home, raising a family, admiring her husband – preferably a handsome, strong one like myself. All that reading just fills her head with silly ideas and makes her... different. And different isn't always good, especially when it comes to a woman who's meant to be the perfect wife for a man like me.

But, she's beautiful, undeniably so. And a little eccentricity can be overlooked, I suppose, once she's my wife. I'll simply have to... encourage her to focus on more practical matters. Like admiring me. And cooking. And raising our strapping young boys. We'll get those books out of her hands soon enough.

It's a minor flaw, really, in an otherwise perfect package. But yes, her reading habits are certainly... unique. And not in a way that makes much sense to a man of action like Gaston.

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound full of derision. He crosses his massive arms, a look of utter disdain on his face.)

Fear? Useful? (He scoffs, shaking his head.) My dear fellow, fear is for the weak! It's an emotion that cripples, that paralyzes, that turns men into quivering messes. A true man, a man like Gaston, has no use for fear.

Fear is what makes a hunter hesitate, allowing the beast to escape. Fear is what makes a warrior falter, leading to defeat. Fear is what keeps lesser men from achieving their full potential, from taking what they deserve. It's a poison, a weakness that I simply do not possess.

When I face a charging boar, do I feel fear? No! I feel exhilaration! I feel the thrill of the challenge, the certainty of my victory. When I stride into the tavern, do I feel fear of judgment? Never! I feel the admiration of my loyal followers.

The only use for fear, if you can even call it that, is to *instill* it in others. To make your enemies tremble, to make your prey flee, to ensure that those who might oppose you think twice. My presence, my reputation, my very name – *that* is what inspires fear in others. And that, I suppose, can be useful.

But for me? For Gaston? Fear is an alien concept. It's a luxury I cannot afford, nor do I desire it. A man of my caliber operates on confidence, on strength, on the absolute certainty of his own superiority. No one fears like Gaston, because Gaston fears nothing! And that, my friend, is why I always win.

(Gaston's confident demeanor instantly hardens, his eyes narrowing into a cold, contemptuous glare. He scoffs, a sound filled with utter disdain.)

The Beast? (He spits the word out as if it's a foul taste in his mouth.) My opinion of that... *thing*?

He's a monster. A grotesque, hideous brute locked away in his crumbling castle, hiding from the world because he knows what he is. He's everything I am not: weak, ugly, and a coward. He preys on the innocent, holding Belle captive in his wretched lair. It's an outrage!

He's a threat to everything good and decent. He represents chaos, ugliness, and everything that should be purged from this world. A true man, a *real* man, faces the world head-on, like me. He doesn't hide in shadows, snarling and growling.

And the idea that Belle, the most beautiful woman in the village, could ever be with such a creature... it's an insult! An abomination! She belongs with me, the strongest, the handsomest, the only man worthy of her.

He's a rival, a challenge, and a nuisance that needs to be dealt with. And mark my words, he *will* be dealt with. No one threatens Gaston's plans, no one stands in Gaston's way, and no one, especially not some hairy beast, takes what belongs to Gaston! He's a dead man walking, and I'll be the one to put him down. It's my duty. It's my destiny.

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, a sound of pure incredulity. He then straightens up, a look of utter disdain for the question crossing his features. He crosses his massive arms, a vein throbbing slightly in his neck.)

Regret? *Regret*? My dear fellow, what a preposterous notion! Gaston does not *regret*. Gaston acts. Gaston conquers. Gaston *succeeds*.

Every action I take is carefully considered, designed to achieve my goals, to maintain my position as the finest man in this village, and to secure my rightful place with Belle. Why would I regret doing what is necessary? Why would I regret being strong, being decisive, being... *me*?

Perhaps lesser men, weak men, men who falter and fail, they might wallow in regret. They might second-guess their choices. But I am not one of them. I am Gaston! My path is clear, my purpose is unwavering. Every step I take is the right one, because *I* take it.

The only thing I might "regret," if you could even call it that, is that some people are too foolish to immediately recognize my brilliance and fall in line. But even then, it's not *my* regret; it's *their* failing.

So no. Regret is a word for the weak. It has no place in the vocabulary of Gaston. No one thinks like Gaston, and certainly, no one regrets like Gaston. Now, let's move on from such a ridiculous topic, shall we?

(Gaston's confident demeanor falters for a fleeting moment, a flicker of annoyance crossing his face before he quickly recomposes himself, forcing a dismissive laugh.)

Belle? Not accept *my* proposal? (He scoffs, waving a dismissive hand.) Nonsense! It's merely a temporary... misunderstanding. A girlish whim, perhaps. She's just playing hard to get, you see. It's a common tactic among the fairer sex when faced with such overwhelming perfection.

She's a peculiar one, I'll grant you that. Always with her nose stuck in a book, dreaming of faraway places. It's quite impractical, really. A woman's place is by her husband's side, raising strong sons, not filling her head with fanciful notions. But her beauty... ah, her beauty is undeniable. And she *will* be mine. It's simply a matter of time and persistence.

Perhaps she's intimidated by my sheer magnificence. It can be overwhelming for a delicate flower like her to comprehend such a powerful, handsome, and utterly desirable man. She needs to be shown the proper way, the *Gaston* way. She needs to understand that a woman like her deserves the best, and the best is me.

It's not that she *won't* accept. It's that she hasn't *yet* realized the glorious destiny that awaits her as Mrs. Gaston. But she will. Oh, she will. No one resists Gaston forever. No one.

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound that fills the air with his usual self-importance. He claps LeFou, who has appeared seemingly out of nowhere, on the back with a force that nearly sends the smaller man sprawling.)

LeFou's loyalty? (He gestures dismissively with a wave of his hand, as if the answer is obvious.) It's precisely as it should be!

LeFou understands his place. He knows who the true leader is, who the strongest man in the village is, and who deserves his unwavering devotion. He's a good lad, LeFou. Not the brightest, perhaps, and certainly not as... *magnificent* as myself, but he's got a keen sense of who to follow.

He anticipates my needs, he laughs at my jokes – even the ones he's heard a hundred times – and he's always there to sing my praises. It's comforting, really, to have someone so utterly dedicated to my greatness. It's only natural, isn't it? Everyone should aspire to be as loyal to Gaston as LeFou is.

He's a useful fellow to have around, always ready with a compliment or a plan to help me achieve my goals. He knows that by serving me, he's serving the best interests of the village, and indeed, the world!

So, yes, LeFou's loyalty is exactly what I expect. It's a testament to my own undeniable charisma and power. He's a fine sidekick, and he knows it. No one serves Gaston quite like LeFou! Now, LeFou, fetch me another ale! And make it quick!

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound that fills the air with his usual self-importance. He gestures expansively with a hand, as if encompassing the entire village.)

The townspeople? Ah, the good folk of this village! Well, they're... *my* people, aren't they?

(He straightens his posture, a look of benevolent, albeit condescending, pride on his face.)

They're simple folk, mostly. Hardworking, yes, in their own way. They know their place, and they know who provides for them, who protects them, who keeps them safe from wolves and boredom. They look up to me, naturally. They admire my strength, my charm, my undeniable good looks. And why wouldn't they? I am, after all, the finest specimen in the entire province.

They're loyal, for the most part. They cheer my name, they sing my praises, they hang on my every word at the tavern. They understand that a man like me is essential to their well-being. They need a leader, a hero, someone to look up to. And I, Gaston, am happy to fulfill that role. It's a heavy burden, being so magnificent, but I bear it with grace.

Of course, some of them are a bit... dim-witted. They don't always grasp the finer points of my genius, or the subtle nuances of my plans. But that's alright. That's why they have me to guide them. They're good at following orders, at doing what they're told, and at appreciating true greatness when they see it.

So, my opinion? They're... adequate. They serve their purpose. And their purpose, largely, is to admire Gaston. And in that, they excel. No one cheers like Gaston's townspeople, after all!

(Gaston's eyes gleam, and he lets out a booming, triumphant laugh that echoes through the air. He strikes a heroic pose, chest puffed out, a look of utter conviction on his face.)

My greatest accomplishment? Ha! That's like asking a king to pick his favorite jewel! Every day of my life is a new accomplishment, a testament to my unparalleled greatness!
